comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Those cannon look like captured Russian ones from the siege of Sevastopol in the Crimean War (1855). Pairs were sent to every major city in the British Empire - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Sevastopol_(1854%E2%80%931855) . Recently did some digging on two in Sydney, Australia - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362659579/

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] They look exactly the same, especially the wheels and the curvy stand thing at the back! These upended cannons are near where I live in Dublin. Have heard all manner of stories about where they came from - Napoleonic Wars, or from a 19th century British frigate... Found this on 1861 Belfast / Ulster Street Directory: "Two Russian guns, taken during the Crimean war at Sebastopol - both 46 pounders, and bearing inscriptions in Russian characters - presented to the town as trophies, are now mounted in a commanding position, upon the front esplanade of this fine suite of public buildings - for ornament alone, of course", though these two were placed near the Custom House.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content:
The Pilot Office stood on the north side of the Lagan at the entrance to Spencer Dock.  Spencer Dock, Dufferin Dock and York Dock were all enlarged, so where the Pilot Office stood is probably under water now - coordinates are about 54.612026,-5.913563.
The Pilot Office had been described as "a collapsed telescope in the Tudor manner".  The cannon are from the Crimean War.
There are two ships being built in the background at the shipyards of Workman, Clark & Co.  This company began in 1879 and pioneered the development of the refrigerated steamer.  At their peak Workman, Clark employed over 12,000 employees and was described in Belfast as the "Wee Yard".  It occupied 80 acres on the north side of the River Lagan and closed in 1935.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] Thanks Gerry, for the co-ordinates and the shipyard information especially the "Wee Yard" - that kind of local and colloquial knowledge is invaluable to us! So nothing here to dispute a date of 1890 then?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It looks like the track they are laying has wooden rails with iron capping, which must have been for horse-drawn trams, rather than trains (?). I was trying to find out about tramways in Belfast (earliest 1872, electrified 1904), and came across this amazing film - take a 1901 ride on the top deck of a Belfast horse-drawn tram - youtu.be/SpU4DgefFPo

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] That film is absolutely gorgeous, thank you! I had never seen or heard of such a method of advertising films as the men with the wheeled adverts - tremendous. I wonder how much they got paid for wheeling them around Belfast, and did that happen in all cities at the time...

With regard to the tracks, I'm not sure about trams. Would there not have been far more of a need for trains to reach the docks? The sleepers, etc. really implied trains to me, but I know that one of you will know for sure...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The tracks are a form of Baulk Road for the internal dock railway. No high speeds involved but capable of taking heavy loads. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baulk_road They had a lot of spare timber as can be seen from the staging in the background. The film is really good quality by Mitchell and Kenyon, with a voice-over by Professor Vanessa Toulmin. She puts on the Showzam fairground in Blackpool Winter Gardens each February half-term holiday. www.nfa.dept.shef.ac.uk/intro/toulmin.html Some of those trams have women passengers on the top deck without Decency Boards. Shock! Horror!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] No Decency Boards?! Think of your blood pressure - you better have another quiet lie down in a dark room...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Thanks for that explanation. There is so much to learn about train and tramway history. I do not mean to hog this photo, but it stretched my imagination enough to check whether the ship being built in the middle by Workman, Clark & Co., might just have been the 'Polly Woodside', which still exists in Melbourne, Australia - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polly_Woodside . She was launched there in 1885, before this photo (?). Unfortunately, the windows / portholes do not match, but the turtle-back stern does. Oh well, someone might be interested ...

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I was on the "Polly Woodside" in 1977, when the hull was being covered with new steel plates. It was still a building site in the dry dock on the Yarra. All comments welcome about the unusual wooden railway shown above. The grooved rail section without a flat foot has me puzzled. There must have been a large enough order to make it worthwhile rolling. More research needed. So maybe it was used by Belfast Tramways. Who knows what lies a couple of inches beneath the tarmac in Belfast? I remember a burst water main in Elizabeth Street, Melbourne at the junction with Flinders Street. The water force lifted lots of tarred wooden blocks around the tram tracks. They had been hidden under the tarmac. Newcastle-upon-Tyne also had wooden streets in the city centre. They were quieter than cobblestone setts.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: The track is for dockyard railway - definitely not trams!

comment._content: Crane Tracks possibly?

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Wooden railways were earlier than canals in Great Britain. County Durham had miles of horse-drawn waggonways in the late 1600s, to take coal from the mines down to the Tyne and Wear. Iron rails date from the early 1800s. Then the Hedley brothers developed steam locos "Puffing Billy" and "Wylam Dilly". George Stephenson came later and the rest is history..... Here is a wooden waggonway discovered in County Durham. sine.ncl.ac.uk/view_image.asp?digital_doc_id=2841 Landscape photograph (taken during excavations) looking along the length of the Lambton Waggonway showing sleepers, rails and points. (Image from 20 March 1996)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Groovy!  Any idea haw the wooden rails were attached to the sleepers?  It seems like a weak point, with the square of the hypotenuse and all that.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]  They seem to have set out the sleepers first, then roughly laid out the wooden rails. There are gaps above some sleepers.
It looks like they are using the grooved rails to bridge the gap between wooden rails.
Next would be packing above some sleepers. Only then would the gauge be set, by what method I don't know. I think the track is still there under the tarmac (bitumen).
The new tram track in Blackpool does not have stretcher bars. The gauge is maintained  by the mass of concrete around the rails. Only time will tell.
